contentrichtext.text: {{Refimprove|date=December 2009}} {| class="infobox bordered" | colspan="2" style="text-align: center; background-color: #f40;"|'''Tōkai region''' Data |- | colspan="3" style="text-align: center; background-color: orange;"|Sum of 4 prefectures |- | style="text-align: center; background-color: #f0f0f0;"|Area | style="text-align: right;"|'''29,316.53'''km² |- | style="text-align: center; background-color: #f0f0f0;"|Total population | style="text-align: right;"|'''15,138,397'''<br />（March 1, 2010） |- | style="text-align: center; background-color: #f0f0f0;"|Population density | style="text-align: right;"|'''516.37''' per km²<br />（March 1, 2010） |- | colspan="3" style="text-align: center; background-color: orange;"|Map |- | colspan="3" style="text-align: center; font-size: smaller;"|[[File:Tokai-region Small.png|right|Region map]] |- |} The {{Nihongo|'''Tōkai region'''|東海地方|Tōkai-chihō}} is a sub-region of the [[Chūbu region]] in [[Japan]] that runs along the [[Pacific Ocean]]. The name means "East sea" and comes from the [[Tōkaidō]], one of the [[Edo Five Routes]]. Because Tōkai is a sub-region and is not officially classified, there is some disagreement about where exactly the region begins and ends, however Japanese maps widely conclude that the region includes [[Shizuoka Prefecture|Shizuoka]], [[Aichi Prefecture|Aichi]], [[Gifu Prefecture|Gifu]] and [[Mie Prefecture|Mie]] prefectures. The largest major city in the region is [[Nagoya]] and the [[Chūkyō Metropolitan Area]] (Nagoya Metropolitan Area) makes up a large portion of the region and has Japan's third strongest economy. The business influence of this urban area sometimes extends out into the outlying areas of the three prefectures centered around Nagoya which are Aichi, Gifu, and Mie; this area is sometimes referred to as the Chūkyō region. Tōkai is a heavy manufacturing area and is one of the most industrial regions in Japan. Its coast is lined with densely populated cities with economies that thrive on factories. The Tōkai region has experienced a number of [[Tokai earthquakes|large earthquakes]] in the past, including the two great earthquakes in 1944 (also known as the "Tonankai earthquake") and 1945 (also known as the "Mikawa earthquake").<ref>Karan, Pradyumna Prasad. (2005). {{Google books|vSDLLpn4K4UC|''Japan in the 21st Century: Environment, Economy, and Society,'' p. 36|page=36}}.</ref> Following the work of [[Kiyoo Mogi]], it is predicted that there is a possibility that the area will be subject to a shallow [[Moment magnitude scale|magnitude]] 8.0 [[earthquake]] in the near future.<ref name=mogi-2004>[http://www.terrapub.co.jp/journals/EPS/pdf/2004/5608/5608li.pdf Two grave issues concerning the expected Tokai Earthquake] Kiyoo Mogi, ''Earth Planets Space'', Vol. 56 (No. 8), pp. li-lxvi, published 2004, accessed 2011-03-11</ref> [[Nagoya]], [[Shizuoka City|Shizuoka]], and other large cities would be greatly damaged, with casualties in the thousands, if not millions, making it one of the worst disasters on Earth. The [[Coordinating Committee for Earthquake Prediction]] designated the region as an Area of Specific Observation in 1970, and upgraded it to an Area of Intensified Observation in 1974.<ref name=mogi-2004 /> ==Railroads== [[Central Japan Railway Company]], an arm of the former national railway [[Japan Railways Group]], operates in an area roughly coextensive with the Tōkai region. In fact, JR Central's legal Japanese name is ''Tōkai Railway Company'', abbreviated to ''JR-Tōkai'' ("JR Central" is the English name). JR Central operates the [[Tōkaidō Main Line]] between [[Atami Station|Atami]] and [[Maibara Station|Maibara]] stations, as well as the [[Tōkaidō Shinkansen]] high speed line between [[Tokyo Station|Tokyo]] and [[Shin-Ōsaka Station|Shin-Ōsaka]], and many conventional lines joining with the Tōkaidō Main Line. ==Companies== *[[Toyota Motor Company]] *[[Yamaha]] *[[Kawai Musical Instruments]] ==Universities== *[[Nagoya University]] *[[Nanzan University]] *[[Nagoya Institute of Technology]] *[[Gifu University]] *[[Mie University]] *[[Chukyo University]] *[[Toyohashi University of Technology]] *[[Nihon University College of International Relations]] ==Airports== *[[Chubu Centrair International Airport]] *[[Nagoya Airport|Nagoya Regional Airport]] ==Sports clubs== ===Baseball=== *[[Chunichi Dragons]] ===Football=== *[[Júbilo Iwata]] *[[Nagoya Grampus]] *[[Shimizu S-Pulse]] *[[F.C.
